questions.text: Seema is a 32-year-old office worker who spends most of her day sitting at her desk typing on her computer. Over the past few weeks, she has been experiencing pain and numbness in her right arm, particularly in her hand and fingers. She has also noticed a weakening grip and occasional tingling sensation in her right arm. Her X-ray neck was performed which is shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B. Cervical Rib

 

Option B:

 

The given scenario describes thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS), a condition where the nerves and blood vessels that pass through the thoracic outlet become compressed.

 

Most commonly C8, T1 roots are affected.

 

Cervical Rib - A cervical rib is an extra rib that forms above the first normal rib, arising from the C7 vertebra. It can lead to thoracic outlet syndrome if it compresses on nerves or blood vessels, resulting in symptoms like pain, numbness, tingling, and weakness in the arm and hand, as described in the patient's presentation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Costochondritis: This is inflammation of the cartilage that connects a rib to the sternum, which can cause chest pain. The pain from costochondritis may be mistaken for a heart attack or other heart conditions, but it doesn't usually cause numbness in the arm or hands.

 

Option C. Rib Fracture 2nd / 3rd: A fracture in one of the first three ribs can be serious due to the protection they provide to vital chest organs. However, fractures typically present with localized pain and difficulty breathing rather than the arm and hand symptoms described by the patient.

 

Option D. C5/C6 Spondylolisthesis: This is a condition where one of the vertebrae in the spine slips out of place onto the vertebra below it, which could be due to a defect or fracture. It can cause localized neck pain and potentially radicular symptoms, but not typically the hand and arm symptoms noted by the patient unless associated with significant nerve root compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with thoracic outlet syndrome, likely caused by a cervical rib compressing the brachial plexus or subclavian vessels, as can be seen on the neck X-ray with a bony structure arising from the cervical vertebra.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 216

questions.text: A patient presented with pleuritic chest pain and absent breath sounds on the right side. A dull note is felt on percussion. What is the best chest x-ray view to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Right Lateral decubitus view

 

Option D:

 

Lateral decubitus view is the best view to identify pleural effusion. It can identify as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid.

 

Right Lateral decubitus view - For suspected right-sided pleural effusion, the right lateral decubitus view is best. The patient lies on the right side, and if pleural fluid is present, it will shift and layer in the pleural space, creating a meniscus that is visible on the x-ray.

 

Explanation:

 

 

Option A. PA view: The posteroanterior (PA) view is a standard chest x-ray view that provides an overview of the lungs, heart, and great vessels. It's useful for many thoracic conditions but may not always be the best option to detect small pleural effusions.

 

Option B. Right anterior oblique (RAO): This view allows for better visualization of the lung fields and is commonly used to visualize the heart, great vessels, and posterior ribs. However, it's not typically used for identifying pleural effusions.

 

Option C. Left Lateral decubitus view: This position is useful when looking for pleural effusions on the left side. In this view, the patient lies on their left side, and free pleural fluid shifts, allowing better visualization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The right lateral decubitus view is the most sensitive chest x-ray position to identify pleural effusion on the right side. It can detect as little as 25 ml of pleural fluid, demonstrating the meniscus sign and blunting of the costophrenic angle. For comprehensive assessment, ultrasonography remains the most sensitive imaging modality, capable of detecting even smaller volumes of pleural fluid.

 

Features of chest radiograph in pleural effusion:

 

SIGN: meniscus sign/ Ellis S curve

 

EARLIEST FINDING: blunting of CP angle

 

MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: C/L shift

 

MOST SENSITIVE IX: USG (can pick up 10 -20 ml)

 

MOST SENSITIVE X RAY – I/L lateral decubitus

 

 

Figure 1 Image showing Pleural effusion – Source: - Wikipedia

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient with Marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness and a sharp pain in his chest. He had been lifting heavy objects and moving around a lot that day. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pneumothorax

 

Option A:

 

The chest X-ray demonstrating tracheal deviation and displacement of the heart away from the affected side along with the partial collapse of the right lung points to a diagnosis of left-sided pneumothorax. Primary spontaneous pneumothorax may be seen in a patient with Marfanoid habitus.

 

Pneumothorax:

 

MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: Contralateral

 

MOST SENSITIVE IX: CT scan

 

MOST SENSITIVE X-RAY: Expiratory X ray

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pleural Effusion: This typically shows up on an X-ray as a homogenous shadow that may obscure the lung base and potentially cause blunting of the costophrenic angle. In more significant effusions, there might be a meniscus sign, but there would not be lung collapse as seen with pneumothorax.

 

Option C. Consolidation: Common signs include air bronchograms, which are not seen in this X-ray, making consolidation an unlikely diagnosis here.

 

Option D. Aortic Dissection: This would not directly affect lung volumes or cause tracheal deviation, and it is typically diagnosed with a CT scan rather than a chest X-ray, as it may show a widened mediastinum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The chest X-ray demonstrates a tracheal deviation away from the affected side and displacement of the heart, with partial collapse of the right lung consistent with a left-sided pneumothorax, which can be associated with Marfan syndrome, a condition known for its connective tissue anomalies.

 

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 14

questions.text: A 35-year-old alcoholic patient presents with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea after an episode of intense retching. CT scan is shown here. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pneumomediastinum

 

Option C:

 

The given clinical scenario of Boerhaave syndrome and CT scan showing air around the mediastinal structures and subcutaneous emphysema is suggestive of pneumomediastinum.

 

Pneumomediastinum is the presence of extraluminal gas within the mediastinum.

 

 Pneumomediastinum - This is the presence of air within the mediastinal structures and is the correct diagnosis for a patient with Boerhaave syndrome, where intense retching causes esophageal rupture. On CT, air can be seen outlining the mediastinal structures such as the heart and trachea.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: On CT, this would be visible as a clear space with no lung markings adjacent to the lung.

 

Option B. Pneumoperitoneum: It is not related to the chest but rather the abdominal cavity and would be considered in cases of gastrointestinal perforation.

 

Option D. Consolidation: On a CT scan, consolidation presents as an area of increased density in the lung parenchyma and is associated with inflammatory infiltrates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea following intense retching, the CT scan finding of air surrounding the mediastinal structures is indicative of pneumomediastinum, a common radiological sign in Boerhaave syndrome. This condition is characterized by full-thickness esophageal rupture leading to leakage of air into the mediastinum.

 

Signs of pneumomediastinum:

 

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 28

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath following a motor vehicle accident. On examination, decreased breath sounds are noted on the left side. Bedside ultrasonography is performed, and the image shown is obtained using M-mode. Which of the following signs is most likely being depicted in this ultrasound image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Seashore sign

 

Option A:

 

In M-mode ultrasound, this sign indicates normal lung sliding, where there is motion between the visceral and parietal pleura. On the monitor, above the pleural line, motionless chest wall soft tissue creates a pattern resembling static waves, while the granular appearance below the pleural line is created by the sliding lung, resembling the sandy texture of a seashore.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Stratosphere sign: Also known as the barcode sign, this pattern is seen in M-mode when lung sliding is absent, such as in pneumothorax. It's characterized by parallel lines above and below the pleural line, resembling a barcode or a stratospheric pattern, without the sandy appearance of lung sliding.

 

Option C. Lung point sign: This sign is specific for pneumothorax in B-mode ultrasonography. It is the point at which the normal seashore sign and the abnormal stratosphere sign meet, indicating the presence of both lung tissue and the air of a pneumothorax side by side.

 

Option D. Sinusoidal sign: This sign is indicative of a 'flapping' motion of the heart or the IVC in M-mode and is typically associated with cardiac pathologies like pericardial effusion or exaggerated IVC collapsibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The seashore sign on M-mode ultrasonography is indicative of normal lung sliding, seen at the pleural lining due to relative motion between the two pleural layers. This is the M-mode counterpart of lung sliding seen in B-mode ultrasound, where motion of the lung deep to the pleura causes a grainy appearance, simulating the appearance of sand at a seashore.

 

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 14

questions.text: What is the most commonly done chest X-ray view?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. PA view

 

Option A:

 

PA View - The Postero-Anterior (PA) view is the most standard and commonly performed view in chest radiography. The X-ray beam passes from the posterior (back) to the anterior (front) of the chest. This view provides a clear image of the lungs, heart, and thoracic cavity without significant magnification of the heart, which can occur in other views.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. AP View: The Antero-Posterior (AP) view is typically used in situations where the patient cannot stand or sit upright for a PA view, such as in the bed-bound or severely ill patients. The X-ray beam passes from the anterior (front) to the posterior (back) of the chest. This view can result in a magnified image of the heart, making it less ideal for evaluating cardiac silhouette and lung fields.

 

Option C. Lateral View: The lateral chest view is often done in conjunction with the PA view to provide a side view of the chest. It is helpful for identifying abnormalities seen on the PA view in more detail, determining the location of abnormalities within the thorax, and identifying issues that may not be visible on a PA view, such as lesions in the retrosternal or retrocardiac spaces.

 

Option D. Oblique View: Oblique views are less commonly used and are specialized views taken at an angle. They are typically reserved for specific indications, such as better visualization of the ribs or certain lung segments, and are not part of the routine chest X-ray series.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The postero-anterior (PA) view is the most commonly performed chest X-ray view, offering clear visualization of the thoracic structures with minimal distortion, usually taken in full inspiration and an upright position.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with a history of fever and chest pain for the last 17 days. A chest X-ray was done. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Loculated pleural effusion

 

Option A:

 

The above X-ray is suggestive of loculated pleural effusion.

 

The chest X-ray shows obliteration of left costophrenic angle with a wide pleural-based dome-shaped opacity projecting into the lung.

 

Loculated pleural effusion - On the X-ray, it may appear as a pleural-based dome-shaped opacity with an obtuse angle relative to the chest wall, indicative of fluid within the pleural space rather than lung parenchyma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: On an X-ray, it would appear as an area of increased radiolucency without vascular markings, and there may be a visible rim of air outlining the collapsed lung, but no dome-shaped opacity.

 

Option C. Consolidation: On an X-ray, it appears as a homogenous increase in pulmonary parenchymal opacity that may obscure the lung markings and possibly air bronchograms, and it makes an acute angle with the chest wall.

 

Option D. Fibrosis: On the X-ray, there would typically be reticular or reticulonodular patterns, volume loss, and architectural distortion, not a pleural-based dome-shaped opacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct diagnosis is loculated pleural effusion, which on the chest X-ray appears as a pleural-based, dome-shaped opacity that obliterates the costophrenic angle and forms an obtuse angle with the chest wall. This indicates a collection of fluid in the pleural space, separated by fibrinous adhesions, and is an indication for pigtail drainage.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 12

questions.text: Meena is a 50-year-old woman who was recently hospitalized with pneumonia. She had been experiencing a persistent cough, fever, and chest pain for several days. Upon arrival at the hospital, she was diagnosed with pneumonia and started on antibiotics. Despite treatment with antibiotics, her symptoms did not improve. In fact, her cough became worse, and she developed a high fever. A chest X-ray revealed the presence of a pleural effusion. A CECT was done which is shown here. What is the probable cause of non-improvement of Meena’s fever?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Empyema

 

Option C:

 

The CECT shows a split pleura sign which is described in empyema.

 

Empyema - Empyema refers to the collection of pus in the pleural space and is a complication of pneumonia or thoracic surgery. A "split pleura sign" seen on a CECT scan is suggestive of empyema. It indicates the presence of a pleural peel or thickening, which is characteristic of empyema, rather than simple fluid or transudate, which is more characteristic of uncomplicated parapneumonic effusions or hydrothorax.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antibiotic resistance: This is a potential cause for the non-improvement of a bacterial infection despite antibiotic treatment. It occurs when bacteria change in a way that reduces or eliminates the effectiveness of antibiotics. However, antibiotic resistance would not explain the physical findings on the CECT.

 

Option B. Wrong diagnosis: If Meena's initial symptoms were misdiagnosed and she was not treated for the correct condition, it could lead to persistent or worsening symptoms. However, the presence of a pleural effusion on the chest X-ray supports a diagnosis related to a pleural disease process.

 

Option D. Hydrothorax: Hydrothorax is the accumulation of serous fluid in the pleural space. While it can be associated with pneumonia, the presence of the "split pleura sign" on CECT is more specific for empyema rather than simple hydrothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "split pleura sign" on CECT is indicative of empyema, which is an accumulation of pus in the pleural space, typically arising as a complication of pneumonia. This finding, alongside her clinical picture of worsening symptoms despite antibiotics, suggests that Meena has an empyema that may require drainage.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 12

questions.text: The chest radiograph of a patient showed silhouetting of the left border of the heart. Pathology of which part of the lung does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Lingula

 

Option D:

 

Silhouetting of the left border of the heart indicates a pathology in the lingula segments.

 

Lingula - The lingula is part of the left lung, anatomically adjacent to the left heart border. Pathology here would indeed cause silhouetting of the left heart border due to the anatomical proximity, following the silhouette sign principle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Right lower lobe: If there was pathology in the right lower lobe, it would likely silhouette the right diaphragm on a chest radiograph, not the left heart border.

 

Option B. Hilar: Pathology in the hilar region could potentially obscure the heart borders, but it is more central and would likely affect both sides rather than selectively the left heart border.

 

Option C. Apex of left lower lobe: Pathology at the apex of the left lower lobe would be higher up in the thoracic cavity and would not typically cause silhouetting of the left heart border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The silhouette sign indicates that an opacity on a chest radiograph is in anatomical contact with the structure that has been silhouetted. In this case, silhouetting of the left heart border indicates a pathology in the lingula of the lung.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with the history of cough for one week. He also gives a history of hemoptysis for 1 month and fever for 4 days. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. RML consolidation

 

Option A:

 

The X-ray shown above indicates consolidation due to presence of opacities in the right middle lobe silhouetting the right heart border along with the history of fever, cough and hemoptysis.

 

Silhouette sign

 

 

 

  • When the markings of heart are not visible – silhouette sign positive – localized to middle lobe /lingula
  • When the markings of heart are visible – silhouette sign negative – localized to lower lobe.

 

Right Middle Lobe (RML) consolidation - In the X-ray, the silhouette sign is positive with the right heart border not clearly visible, suggesting the pathology is located in an area that is anatomically adjacent to the heart, such as the RML.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Right Lower Lobe (RLL) consolidation: If there were consolidation in the RLL, it would typically cause blunting or obliteration of the right diaphragm due to effacement of the angle between the diaphragm and the lung, and the heart border would remain visible.

 

Option C. Right Upper Lobe (RUL) consolidation: RUL consolidation typically does not affect the visibility of the heart borders, but rather, it may show up as opacification in the upper zones of the right lung, with preservation of the heart borders.

 

Option D. Pericardial effusion: It would present as an enlarged cardiac silhouette or "water bottle" sign, which is not evident in the provided X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of the silhouette signs with the loss of the right heart border on the X-ray, along with clinical symptoms of fever, cough, and hemoptysis, points to consolidation in the RML.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 38

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of chronic heart failure presents to the emergency department with increased shortness of breath and a productive cough with white sputum. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion at the right lung base. A chest radiograph is ordered. Air bronchogram on CXR may be seen in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pleural effusion

 

Option C:

 

In pleural effusion, there is a homogenous opacity with absent broncho-vascular markings, obliteration of costophrenic angle, and no air bronchogram.

 

Air bronchogram is defined as a pattern of air-filled bronchi (dark) on a background of opacified lung (grey/white). It is almost always caused by a pathological alveolar process, in which something other than air fills the alveoli.

 

Pleural effusion - Air bronchograms are not seen in pleural effusion because the problem lies in the pleural space rather than within the alveoli. On X-ray, pleural effusion is noted by a fluid level in the pleural space and blunting of the costophrenic angle.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Consolidation: Air bronchograms are commonly seen in consolidation as air-filled bronchi are made visible by the surrounding alveoli that are filled with fluid, cells, or other material, which is opaque on X-ray.

 

Option B. Pulmonary edema: Air bronchograms may be seen in pulmonary edema when the alveolar spaces are filled with fluid, although it's more typical to see diffuse hazy opacities indicative of interstitial fluid.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: In lymphoma involving the lungs, one may see a mass or nodular lesions rather than the classic air bronchogram pattern; however, if the lymphoma leads to airspace occupation, it could potentially cause an air bronchogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Air bronchogram is not observed in pleural effusion, as this condition is characterized by fluid accumulation in the pleural space, not within the alveoli, which would otherwise be necessary to create the contrast seen with air bronchograms on imaging.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 12

questions.text: A 35-year-old smoker male underwent a HRCT chest. What is the likely diagnosis based on the CT shown:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pulmonary hamartoma

 

Option D:

 

Explanation:

 

Popcorn calcification is seen in pulmonary hamartoma.

 

A pulmonary hamartoma is the most common benign tumor that arises from the lung tissue.

 

Pulmonary hamartomas are made up of disorganized tissue, including cartilage, fat, and connective tissue. The presence of fat and calcification in a well-circumscribed solitary pulmonary nodule diagnostic of a pulmonary hamartoma.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 80

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with known HIV presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and fever accompanied by chills. Given the chest X-ray findings and patient history, which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pneumococcal Pneumonia

 

Option A:

 

Pneumococcal pneumonia will present with a lobar consolidation and not the characteristic miliary pattern as shown in the image.

 

Pneumococcal pneumonia typically presents with lobar consolidation, often involving a single lobe of the lung. The x-ray would show an area of increased opacity, indicative of the consolidation. This is in contrast to the diffuse, fine nodular pattern seen in the provided image, which is not characteristic of pneumococcal pneumonia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Varicella pneumonia, which can occur in adults with chickenpox, often shows up on x-rays as diffuse nodular opacities. These can sometimes resemble the miliary pattern seen in TB but are generally less uniform and may be associated with areas of consolidation due to secondary bacterial infection.

 

Option C. Miliary TB is a disseminated form of tuberculosis that can arise in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS. The chest x-ray typically shows numerous small nodules uniformly distributed throughout the lung fields, resembling millet seeds, which is likely what we see in this patient's x-ray.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection that can mimic miliary TB on imaging. It is endemic in certain areas, particularly in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys, and can cause diffuse nodular patterns on chest x-rays. The nodules are typically uniform and may calcify over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct diagnosis in this case, given the HIV status of the patient and the bilateral multifocal nodular pattern on chest X-ray, is least likely to be pneumococcal pneumonia, which typically presents with lobar consolidation rather than a miliary pattern.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 38

questions.text: A patient present with symptoms of respiratory distress and a history of acute onset chest pain. The chest X-ray provided shows a characteristic radiologic sign. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Left upper lobe collapse

 

Option A:

 

Luftsichel sign is seen in left upper lobe collapse.

 

It occurs due to hyperinflation of the superior segment of the left lower lobe. Which superimposes between the mediastinum and the collapsed left upper lobe.

 

Luftsichel sign (German: Luft - air and Sichel - sickle). Together, it means crescent of air. It can be seen between the aortic arch and the medial border of the collapsed lung

 

The Luftsichel sign, as shown in the chest X-ray, is indicative of a left upper lobe collapse. This sign occurs due to hyperinflation of the superior segment of the left lower lobe, which interposes between the mediastinum and the collapsed left upper lobe, creating a sickle-shaped area of increased translucency on the radiograph.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lingula collapse usually presents with an opacity projected over the heart shadow due to its anatomical position adjacent to the left heart border, not typically resulting in the Luftsichel sign.

 

Option C. Left lower lobe collapse often results in opacity and volume loss in the left lower quadrant of the chest X-ray, with the possibility of a mediastinal shift towards the affected side. It does not create a Luftsichel sign.

 

Option D. Aortic dissection might be suspected with widened mediastinum or abnormal aortic contour on chest X-ray but would not cause the Luftsichel sign. An aortic dissection would also typically present with very different clinical symptoms, such as tearing chest pain radiating to the back.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Luftsichel sign, which appears as a crescent of air outlining the hyperinflated superior segment of the left lower lobe on a chest X-ray, is a radiological feature indicative of left upper lobe collapse.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of occupational exposure to dust presents with a cough and dyspnea. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing distinctive radiographic findings. Which of the following conditions is least likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Metastatic lymph node

 

Option D:

 

A ring of calcification at the periphery of a lymph node is known as egg-shell calcification.

 

 While metastatic lymph nodes can calcify, they typically do not present with egg-shell calcification. Metastases usually lead to more solid or central areas of calcification within lymph nodes rather than the peripheral rim of calcification observed in egg-shell calcification.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Silicosis can show the classic finding of egg-shell calcification of the lymph nodes, particularly in chronic cases due to long-term inhalation of silica particles, which are often encountered in mining, sandblasting, and foundry work.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis is known for bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, often with associated calcifications which can have an egg-shell appearance on imaging. This granulomatous disease typically has a characteristic pattern of non-caseating granulomas.

 

Option C. Post-radiation therapy changes in lymph nodes can result in dystrophic calcification within the lymph nodes, leading to the egg-shell appearance. This is a sequelae of the healing process following radiation damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of egg-shell calcification in lymph nodes on a chest X-ray is suggestive of conditions such as silicosis, sarcoidosis, or post-radiation therapy changes, but it is not characteristic of metastatic lymph nodes.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A 59-year-old smoker presents with an incidental finding of a 2 cm nodule on a routine chest X-ray. The nodule is well-defined, non-calcified, and located in the right upper lobe without associated lymphadenopathy. What is the most appropriate next step in the evaluation of this solitary pulmonary nodule (SPN)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. PET-CT

 

Option A:

 

SOLITARY PULMONARY NODULE

 

Solitary pulmonary nodule (SPN) is defined as a relatively well-defined, round or oval, pulmonary parenchymal lesion that is equal to or smaller than 30 mm in diameter. It is surrounded by pulmonary parenchyma and/or visceral pleura and is not associated with lymphadenopathy, atelectasis, or pneumonia.

 

Initial Investigation: CXR-PA

 

IOC: PET-CT (Can show metabolic features + morphological features) > HRCT (Can show morphological features)

 

Gold standard: Biopsy

 

 PET-CT is often used in the evaluation of SPN to assess for metabolic activity, which can help distinguish between benign and malignant lesions. It combines metabolic information from PET with anatomic details from CT, providing both morphological and functional data.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. HRCT offers detailed images of the lung anatomy and can help in assessing the morphology of SPNs, such as edge characteristics and internal structure, which can be suggestive of malignancy. However, it does not provide metabolic information.

 

Option C. MRI is less commonly used in the initial evaluation of SPNs due to its lower sensitivity and specificity in lung tissue compared to CT. It may be used in special circumstances, such as in patients with contraindications to CT.

 

Option D. CT pulmonary angiography is primarily used to evaluate the pulmonary vasculature, especially for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. It is not the investigation of choice for SPNs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For the evaluation of a solitary pulmonary nodule, PET-CT is the most appropriate investigation as it provides both metabolic and morphological information, which is crucial for differentiating between benign and malignant lesions.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 916

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with Raynaud’s phenomenon and tightening of skin of face and extremities presents with dyspnea and bilateral basal rales. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. HRCT

 

Option D:

 

The given clinical scenario of respiratory symptoms along with the history of Raynaud’s phenomenon and tightening of skin of face and extremities is suggestive of Scleroderma / CREST associated interstitial lung disease (ILD).

 

High-resolution CT is the investigation of choice for ILD.

 

NSIP (nonspecific interstitial pneumonia) is more commonly associated with CREST.

 

Hallmark of UIP: Honeycombing

 

HRCT is the gold standard for diagnosing ILD and can differentiate between various patterns of lung disease, such as nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP), which is commonly associated with CREST syndrome, part of the scleroderma spectrum of diseases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MRI is not the imaging modality of choice for initial assessment of interstitial lung disease (ILD) as it offers less detail of lung parenchyma compared to CT.

 

Option B. PET scans are typically utilized for the evaluation of oncologic conditions and are not first-line for diagnosing ILD.

 

Option C. A chest X-ray can reveal changes suggestive of ILD but lacks the detail provided by HRCT, which is essential for assessing the extent and pattern of lung involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with systemic symptoms suggestive of a connective tissue disease like scleroderma and presenting with respiratory complaints, high-resolution CT (HRCT) is the investigation of choice to evaluate for interstitial lung disease.

 

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 84

questions.text: Which of the following structures do not form the hilar shadow in a chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lower lobe veins

 

Option C:

 

Lower lobe veins are not part of the radiological hilum.

 

The radiological hilum is formed by the pulmonary arteries, the upper lobe veins, and the bronchi. The lower lobe pulmonary veins, which pass inferiorly, form no component of the normal hilar shadow. Lymph nodes only contribute to the shadow when enlarged.

 

Most important contribution is from the pulmonary arteries.

 

Lower Lobe Veins - The lower lobe veins are responsible for carrying oxygenated blood from the lower lobes of the lungs back to the heart. However, they do not contribute to the normal hilar shadow because they run inferiorly and posteriorly, outside the confines of the mediastinal hilum as visualized on a standard PA chest X-ray.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pulmonary Artery: The pulmonary arteries are a major component of the hilar shadow on a chest X-ray. They carry deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle of the heart to the lungs for oxygenation. On the X-ray, they contribute significantly to the hilar contour and are typically the uppermost structure in the hilum.

 

Option B.  Bronchus: The main bronchi and their branches also contribute to the hilar shadow. These airways are responsible for conducting air to and from the lungs, and their walls contain cartilage which can be identified on a chest X-ray.

 

Option D. Upper Lobe Veins: The upper lobe veins return oxygenated blood from the upper lobes of the lungs to the heart. These vessels contribute to the hilar shadow on a chest X-ray since they are interposed with other hilar structures and often overlap with the arteries in the hilum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lower lobe veins do not contribute to the radiological hilum on a chest X-ray because they pass inferiorly and form no component of the normal hilar shadow. The hilum is primarily formed by the pulmonary arteries, the upper lobe veins, and the bronchi, with the pulmonary arteries making the most significant contribution. The left hilum typically lies higher than the right, related to the anatomical positioning of the bronchi in relation to the pulmonary arteries.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 30

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient with COPD presents with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath. On auscultation, breath sounds were absent on the left side. What is the best chest x-ray view to diagnose this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. PA view in full expiration

 

Option B:

 

The patient most likely has pneumothorax. The best chest x-ray view to diagnose a pneumothorax is PA view in full expiration.

 

PA view in full expiration - The PA view in full expiration is particularly useful for diagnosing a pneumothorax. On expiration, the lung volume decreases, which can make a small pneumothorax more apparent as there is less lung tissue to mask the presence of air in the pleural space. This view can show a more distinct edge of the lung, separated from the chest wall, which is indicative of a pneumothorax.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A.  PA view in full inspiration: The postero-anterior (PA) view in full inspiration is a standard chest X-ray that provides a clear view of the lungs, heart, and major thoracic structures. It is commonly used for routine assessment of the chest and can detect a wide range of pulmonary conditions. However, for pneumothorax, the inspiratory view may not be as effective as the expiratory view in showing the presence of free air in the pleural space.

 

Option C.  AP view in full inspiration: The antero-posterior (AP) view in full inspiration is typically used when patients cannot stand for a PA view, such as bedridden patients. While it can show lung fields, it may not provide as clear of an image as a PA view due to magnification of the heart and mediastinum.

 

Option D. AP view in full expiration: The DAP (which seems to be a typo and may refer to the AP view) in full expiration is not a standard view and is less commonly used. Expiratory views are not typically performed in the AP position for diagnosing pneumothorax, as the quality of the image may be compromised compared to a PA view.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The best chest X-ray view to diagnose a pneumothorax, particularly in a patient presenting with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath with absent breath sounds on one side, is the PA view in full expiration. This view accentuates the visibility of the pleural space and is more likely to reveal a pneumothorax, especially if it is small and might be missed on a full inspiratory film.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

choices.text: Area of hyperlucency on the ipsilateral side
Mediastinal shift to the ipsilateral side

questions.text: All of the following features can be seen in patients with pneumothorax except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Mediastinal shift to the ipsilateral side

 

Option D:

 

Mediastinal shift to the ipsilateral side - In the case of a pneumothorax, the mediastinum typically shifts to the contralateral side (away from the side of the pneumothorax), especially if it's a tension pneumothorax. This is due to the pressure from the air in the pleural space pushing the mediastinal structures away.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Deep sulcus sign: This is a radiographic finding that can be observed on a supine chest X-ray in the setting of a pneumothorax. It refers to an abnormally deep and sharp costophrenic angle, usually on the side of the pneumothorax, and is more prominent because air collects anteriorly and laterally in a supine patient.

 

Option B. Area of hyperlucency on the ipsilateral side: This describes the appearance of increased radiolucency (darker area) on the side where the pneumothorax is present, indicating the presence of air in the pleural space without underlying lung markings.

 

Option C. Collapse of ipsilateral lung: A pneumothorax can lead to the collapse of the lung on the same side as the air in the pleural space. The degree of lung collapse depends on the size of the pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mediastinal shift to the ipsilateral side is not a feature of a pneumothorax. Instead, a pneumothorax typically causes a contralateral mediastinal shift due to the pressure of air accumulating in the pleural space on the side of the pneumothorax. This shift can be severe in the case of tension pneumothorax, where rapid diagnosis and intervention are critical to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 14

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of industrial exposure to asbestos 30 years ago presents with chest discomfort and dyspnea on exertion. A chest radiograph was obtained to evaluate his symptoms. Which of the following conditions is least likely to be associated with the radiological finding of pleural calcification in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. COVID-19

 

Option D:

 

Explanation:

 

Pleural calcification is not seen in COVID-19.

 

Pleural calcification is a chronic process that occurs after prolonged inflammation or irritation of the pleural layers, leading to the deposition of calcium. It is commonly associated with a history of asbestos exposure (asbestosis), where asbestos fibers cause prolonged pleural irritation, tuberculosis (TB) due to the granulomatous response and healing by calcification, and healed empyema where infection in the pleural space has resolved with calcific scarring. COVID-19, an acute viral infection, has not been associated with pleural calcification as a direct consequence.

 

Educational Objective:


Conditions showing pleural calcification:

 

  • Asbestosis
  • Healed empyema
  • Tuberculosis
  • Previous surgery or radiotherapy

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 8

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with sudden onset dyspnea and left-sided chest pain. On physical examination, you note decreased breath sounds on the left side. Chest radiography is performed. Which of the following is least likely to cause an opaque left hemithorax on the radiograph of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Massive Pneumothorax

 

Option A:

 

  • Pneumothorax would cause a hyperlucent hemithorax.
  • A clear space with no lung markings indicating where the air is present in the pleural space.
  • Visibility of the lung edge as a thin line, separate from the chest wall.
  • Deep sulcus sign seen on the supine X-ray; this is an abnormally deep costophrenic angle.
  • The trachea and mediastinum may be shifted away from the pneumothorax if it is under tension.
  • The affected hemithorax may be more radiolucent (darker on the X-ray) compared to the normal side due to the presence of air.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Massive Pleural Effusion:

 

  • The affected hemithorax appears white or opaque due to fluid replacing the air in the lung field.
  • The border of the diaphragm may be obliterated on the side of the effusion.
  • A meniscus sign may be seen, indicating the fluid level.
  • The mediastinum might be shifted away from the effusion if it is large enough.
  • No lung markings are seen in the area of the effusion.

 

 

Option C. Patient who has undergone pneumonectomy:

 

  • An absence of lung parenchyma on the side of the pneumonectomy.
  • The affected hemithorax may be filled with postoperative changes like fluid or fibrotic tissue.
  • The remaining lung may be hyperinflated and shifted into the space of the removed lung.
  • The trachea and mediastinum may be shifted towards the side of the pneumonectomy.

 

 

 

Option D. Complete main bronchial obstruction:

 

  • Opacity due to lung collapse (atelectasis) behind the obstruction, often leading to a white or opaque hemithorax.
  • Shift of the trachea and mediastinum towards the affected side (volume loss).
  • Elevation of the hemidiaphragm on the affected side due to volume loss.
  • Absence of air bronchograms because air cannot reach the alveoli.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pneumothorax is characterized by the presence of air in the pleural space and typically presents as a hyperlucent area on imaging.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 14

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student who had a history of frequent respiratory infections as a child presents to the OPD. He has been experiencing recurrent episodes of coughing and shortness of breath over the past few months. He also complains of fatigue and chest pain, particularly on the left side. The CT scan reveals a mass in the lower lobe of his left lung as shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Sequestration

 

Option C:

 

Sequestration

 

  • A congenital lung malformation with non-functioning lung tissue that lacks normal communication with the bronchial tree and has an aberrant blood supply from the systemic circulation.
  • Typically located in the lower lobes, more commonly on the left.
  • Diagnosis is often confirmed with CT angiography demonstrating the aberrant blood supply.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hamartoma

 

  • Typically appears as a well-circumscribed, coin-like lesion in the lung periphery.
  • Often contains fat and calcifications, which can be seen on CT as "popcorn calcifications."
  • Generally benign and usually does not cause symptoms unless it compresses surrounding structures.

 

Option B: Lobar Pneumonia

 

  • Presents with lobar consolidation on imaging.
  • Common symptoms include cough, fever, purulent sputum, and pleuritic chest pain.
  • Chest X-ray or CT would show consolidation with air bronchograms, not an isolated mass.

 

Option D: Squamous Cell Carcinoma

 

  • A type of non-small cell lung cancer that typically arises in the central part of the lungs near the hilum.
  • It can cavitate and appear as a central mass on imaging.
  • Risk factors include smoking, occupational exposures, and history of lung diseases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pulmonary sequestration is a congenital lung anomaly characterized by non-functioning lung tissue without normal bronchial communication and systemic arterial supply, most commonly situated in the left lower lobe. Diagnosis is supported by the presence of a systemic feeding vessel on CT angiography.

 

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 124

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with a 2-week history of fever, productive cough, and malaise. The child's immunizations are up-to-date. On examination, you note decreased breath sounds in the right lower lung field. Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a left shift. A chest X-ray reveals a right lower lobe consolidation with a central lucency. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Staphylococcus pneumonia 

 

Option B:

 

A history of fever, cough and the X-ray showing consolidation with an air-filled pneumatocele is characteristic of Staph aureus pneumonia.

 

 Staphylococcus pneumonia

 

  • Can cause pneumonia with pneumatocele formation, particularly in children.
  • Pneumatoceles are thin-walled, air-filled cysts within the lung parenchyma that are characteristic of Staphylococcus aureus infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lung abscess

 

  • Usually results from aspiration pneumonia, characterized by a thick-walled cavity often caused by anaerobic bacteria.
  • It typically takes weeks to form and is often associated with poor dentition or a history of loss of consciousness.

 

Option C. TB cavity

 

  • A feature of reactivation or secondary tuberculosis.
  • Cavities are usually apical and posterior in the upper lobes or superior segment of the lower lobe with thick, fibrotic walls and can contain caseous material.

 

Option D. Pneumothorax

 

  • The presence of air in the pleural space leading to lung collapse.
  • It is characterized by the absence of lung markings beyond the visceral pleural line and no mediastinal shift unless it's a tension pneumothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presentation of fever, cough, and radiological finding of consolidation with central lucency in a child is indicative of Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia. Pneumatoceles, which are air-filled cysts within lung tissue, are commonly associated with this type of infection.

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 38

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with a significant history of weight loss and anorexia, but no cough or hemoptysis, presents for evaluation. A chest X-ray is performed. Based on the imaging findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metastasis

 

Option C:

 

The X-ray depicts the typical cannon ball appearance suggestive of lung metastasis.

 

The 'cannonball' appearance of multiple round nodules on the chest X-ray is suggestive of metastatic disease to the lungs. Metastases are multiple and usually present bilaterally, as shown in the X-ray.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bronchogenic carcinoma often presents with a solitary pulmonary nodule or mass, and may be associated with symptoms such as cough, hemoptysis, or signs of local invasion or metastasis. The X-ray provided does not show a solitary mass typical of a primary lung cancer.

 

Option B. Mesothelioma is a malignancy of the pleural lining often associated with asbestos exposure. It typically presents with pleural thickening and effusion rather than multiple rounded nodules.

 

Option D. Pneumoconiosis, a disease caused by the inhalation of various forms of dust, usually presents with diffuse interstitial patterns on X-ray, not with multiple, well-circumscribed nodules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The typical 'cannonball' appearance of multiple, well-defined nodules on a chest X-ray, as seen in this patient, is suggestive of metastatic disease to the lungs.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 80

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcoholism presents to the emergency department with high-grade fever, cough productive of red currant jelly-like sputum, and right-sided chest pain. On examination, there is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right upper lobe. A chest X-ray reveals a right upper lobe consolidation with a bulging fissure. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. Klebsiella

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Klebsiella pneumoniae

 

  • Known for causing lobar pneumonia in individuals with a predisposition due to alcoholism or diabetes.
  • Characteristic bulging fissure sign and thick, gelatinous sputum production.

 

Option B. Pneumocystis jirovecii

 

  • Typically presents in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV/AIDS.
  • Chest X-ray often shows bilateral, diffuse interstitial infiltrates rather than lobar consolidation.

 

Option C. Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

  • The most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia.
  • Typically presents with lobar consolidation, often associated with rust-colored sputum.

 

Option D. Staphylococcus aureus

 

  • Can cause secondary pneumonia following viral infections like influenza.
  • Often leads to abscess formation and can be associated with empyema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klebsiella pneumoniae pneumonia typically presents with lobar consolidation, bulging fissure sign, and sputum production resembling red currant jelly, particularly in individuals with alcoholism.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 38

questions.text: A cattle handler presents with a cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain. A chest radiograph is performed. Considering the patient's occupational history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hydatid lung

 

Option C:

 

Hydatid lung

 

  • Caused by the parasite Echinococcus granulosus, with patients often presenting with non-specific respiratory symptoms.
  • The "water lily sign" on imaging is characteristic, indicating the presence of a hydatid cyst with floating membranes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lung abscess

 

  • Usually presents as a cavitary lesion with an air-fluid level within the lung parenchyma.
  • Often associated with an acute illness, including fever, productive cough, and pleuritic chest pain.

 

Option B. Pneumatocele

 

  • Appears as a thin-walled air-filled cavity within the lung parenchyma.
  • Commonly results from staphylococcal pneumonia or after trauma.

 

Option D. Emphysematous bullae

 

  • Appear as large air-containing spaces within the lung on chest radiographs.
  • Typically occur in patients with a history of smoking and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with an occupational history of cattle handling, presenting with respiratory symptoms and characteristic imaging features of an air-fluid level with floating membranes, the diagnosis of a hydatid lung caused by Echinococcus granulosus should be considered.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 48

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient presented with fever and non-productive cough for 1 month. Chest x-ray was normal. HRCT is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B. Endobronchial tuberculosis

 

Option B:

 

The above clinical scenario and HRCT showing tree-in-bud sign is suggestive of centrilobular nodules indicating endobronchial spread of tuberculosis.

 

Chronic TB: Cavitation, Fibrosis, Bronchiectasis more commonly in the upper lobes

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alveolar proteinosis

 

  • Characterized by the filling of alveoli with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)-positive proteinaceous material, often showing a "crazy-paving" pattern on HRCT.

 

Option C. Wegener's granulomatosis (now known as Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

 

  • A vasculitic condition that may present with multiple pulmonary nodules, cavitations, and ground-glass opacities, but not typically with a tree-in-bud appearance.

 

Option D. Sarcoidosis

 

  • Typically presents with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and nodular opacities with a perilymphatic distribution, rather than a tree-in-bud pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a patient presenting with a persistent cough and fever, with normal chest X-ray but HRCT showing tree-in-bud sign, the diagnosis of endobronchial tuberculosis should be considered. This is indicative of active bronchogenic dissemination of TB.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 42

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with low grade fever, dry cough and bilateral cheek swelling presents to the OPD. Serum ACE levels are elevated. CXR is shown here. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sarcoidosis

 

Option B:

 

The chest x-ray shows bilateral hilar lymph node enlargement with characteristic clinical features seen in sarcoidosis.

 

 Sarcoidosis

 

  • Characterized by noncaseating granulomas, sarcoidosis often presents with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (often referred to as the 1-2-3 sign or garland sign on X-ray), elevated serum ACE levels, and systemic symptoms like fever and erythema nodosum. The 1-2-3 sign includes right paratracheal, right hilar, and left hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TB (Tuberculosis)

 

  • TB typically presents with cough, night sweats, weight loss, and may show unilateral or bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, along with possible lung field opacities indicative of active pulmonary infection. Caseation necrosis can be seen in the involved lymph nodes.

 

Option C. Silicosis

 

  • An occupational lung disease caused by inhalation of crystalline silica dust, silicosis usually presents with nodular opacities in the upper lobes of the lungs, eggshell calcification of hilar nodes, but not typically with elevated serum ACE levels or bilateral cheek swelling.

 

Option D. Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung

 

  • It may present with a solitary mass, post-obstructive pneumonia, or hilar mass. It is associated with smoking and may lead to hypercalcemia due to the production of parathyroid hormone-related peptide but does not typically cause bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy or cheek swelling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 In a patient with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, low-grade fever, dry cough, bilateral cheek swelling, and elevated serum ACE levels, sarcoidosis should be considered as the likely diagnosis. This condition is characterized radiographically by the 1-2-3 or garland sign, which refers to enlarged right paratracheal, right hilar, and left hilar lymph nodes.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 30

questions.text: A 49-year-old male patient presents with streaky hemoptysis. He has a past history of tuberculosis in childhood. CECT is shown below. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. symptomatic management

 

Option B:

 

Pre-existing cavity with a fungal ball which is mobile showing the Air crescent sign / Monad sign.

 

Management of aspergilloma is symptomatic, and not anti-fungals as there is no invasive fungal infection. In case of severe hemoptysis, Bronchial artery embolization (BAE) or lobectomy would be therapeutic.

 

Symptomatic Management

 

  • For an aspergilloma, which is a fungal ball typically found in a pre-existing lung cavity, the management is often conservative unless complicated by significant or life-threatening hemoptysis. Symptoms like mild hemoptysis can be monitored and treated conservatively, with interventions reserved for more severe cases.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. ATT (Antituberculous Therapy)

 

  • This would be indicated for active tuberculosis, characterized by signs of active infection like fever, weight loss, and night sweats, and confirmed by sputum culture or PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

 

Option C. Voriconazole

 

  • An antifungal medication used for invasive aspergillosis. If the patient had signs of an invasive infection like fever, chest pain, and hemoptysis in an immunocompromised state, this could be indicated. Here, the infection is non-invasive as it's contained within a pre-existing cavity.

 

Option D. Lobectomy

 

  • Surgical removal of a lung lobe is considered for patients with severe or recurrent hemoptysis not manageable by other means, significant symptoms from the mass effect of the aspergilloma, or suspicion of malignancy. It is a more aggressive form of management and not first-line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of treated tuberculosis presenting with hemoptysis and a CECT showing a fungal ball within a pre-existing cavity, symptomatic management is appropriate. This non-invasive form of aspergillosis, known as an aspergilloma, typically does not respond to antifungal therapy due to the avascular nature of the fungal ball. Interventional procedures like bronchial artery embolization or surgery are reserved for severe cases.

 

Ref: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 46

questions.text:
A 65-year-old retired construction worker who has a history of working in construction and insulation for over 20 years, presents to OPD with complaints of shortness of breath, dry cough, and chest discomfort that have been progressively worsening over the past few years.

 

On physical examination, the physician notes decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes of both lungs and crackles heard on auscultation. Spirometry shows a reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) and forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1). HRCT done is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. Round atelectasis

 

Option C:

 

The given case scenario describes asbestosis. Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease that develops as a result of prolonged exposure to asbestos fibers. The fibers cause scarring of the lung tissue, which can lead to breathing difficulties, coughing, and chest pain.

 

The HRCT chest shows a comet-tail sign, seen in cases of round atelectasis.

 

Round atelectasis is associated with asbestos exposure and can appear as a rounded mass on imaging, often with a characteristic 'comet tail' sign caused by the curving of bronchovascular structures into the atelectatic area, which is consistent with the image provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mesothelioma is a form of cancer typically associated with asbestos exposure, involving the pleural lining. It often presents with pleural thickening and effusion, which might not be consistent with the imaging provided.

 

Option B. Bronchogenic carcinoma could be suspected in a patient with this occupational history and symptoms; however, HRCT would usually show a solitary pulmonary nodule or mass rather than the specific pattern seen in this case.

 

Option D. Pulmonary infarct usually presents as a wedge-shaped, pleura-based area of consolidation on imaging and is associated with clinical signs of a pulmonary embolism, which are not described in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with a history of asbestos exposure and symptoms of progressive respiratory compromise, round atelectasis is suggested by HRCT findings that include a 'comet tail' sign, consistent with the enfolding of the pleura and a rounded atelectatic area in the lung.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 104

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with a persistent cough, shortness of breath, and frequent respiratory infections. The patient has been experiencing worsening symptoms despite treatment with antibiotics and airway clearance techniques. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Cystic fibrosis

 

Option C:

 

The HRCT shows cystically dilated upper lobe bronchi with recurrent chest infections suggestive of bronchiectasis in the setting of Cystic fibrosis. HRCT is the investigation of choice for bronchiectasis.

 

Cystic fibrosis is a genetic condition leading to thick, viscous secretions. The HRCT image typically reveals bronchiectasis, which is characterized by cystically dilated airways, particularly in the upper lobes, as well as mucus plugging and frequent infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sarcoidosis is characterized by non-caseating granulomas and often presents with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and lung involvement, but it doesn't typically feature the cystic changes seen in the provided HRCT image.

 

Option B. Silicosis, a pneumoconiosis resulting from inhalation of silica dust, generally shows nodular opacities predominantly in the upper lobes, but unlike cystic fibrosis, it does not present with bronchiectatic changes.

 

Option D. Chronic tuberculosis may lead to fibrosis and scarring in the lung tissue. While it can cause bronchiectasis, the presence of extensive cystic changes and the patient’s age and clinical symptoms are more indicative of cystic fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a young patient with a history of persistent respiratory symptoms and recurrent infections, an HRCT revealing cystically dilated bronchi suggests a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, which is characterized by thick, sticky mucus that can lead to bronchiectasis.

 

Ref:  Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 58
